_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Lightining protection in the control room
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Fire extinquishers located throughout process area
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Closed circuit video in control room and scale house that shows process areas
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Level Transmitter (LT-100B DP Tank, Ammonia Storage T1)
_prev_prog_3.Description: This facility is in full compliance with OSHA PSM. A state-of-the-art secondary containment shell is in place. Acoustical emission testing is conducted on a schedule basis to confirm tank and line integrity. All relief valves are maintained per manufacture's recommendations. Plant operator instructions are updates with each change. Operators are trained on these changes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Tampa Port Services, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of The Mosaic Company, owns and operates the Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal. In this Tampa Port Services distribution facility, we handle anhydrous ammonia, which is considered hazardous by EPA. The same properties that make anhydrous ammonia valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling anhydrous ammonia to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our employees and site workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations, and we are committed to conducting business and operating our facilities in a manner designed to protect the environment, and the health and safety of our employees, and our neighbors around the Ammonia Terminal.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance:

The Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal serves as a vital link in supplying ammonia to its own manufacturing facilities and other customers. Port Sutton receives refrigerated anhydrous ammonia from ships at the Port of Tampa's unloading dock. Ammonia is pumped from the ship to a low pressure storage tank where the ammonia is refrigerated and stored at -28 ?F. Port Sutton may also transfer ammonia via a privately owned pipeline for delivery to Mosaic facilities. The only substance regulated under EPA's RMP requirements at the facility is ammonia.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Polices:

Port Sutton has an extensive safety program to ensure compliance with all applicable local, state and federal rules and regulations. The facility operates under a Corporate Environmental Health and Safety Policy that endorses going beyond regulatory requirements when necessary to protect the health and safety of its employees and the public. The design, maintenance and operation of the facility are carried out in conformance with this policy to provide a

safe operation and to prevent exposures of our employees and nearby neighbors to ammonia. Management at the Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal is responsible for the development and implementation of programs and procedures to ensure conformance with this philosophy. The programs and procedures are continually reviewed and updated, and the facility is periodically audited to assure compliance. Tampa Port Services personnel are also trained in key aspects of emergency response. The facility's Emergency Response Plan is based on OSHA's emergency response standard, 29 CFR 1910.120(q). The plan includes procedures for the notification of local fire and emergency response authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility is linked to a community alarm that provides emergency notification to nearby neighbors. In addition, emergency preparedness is assured by: Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) trained operators and supervisory personnel; emergency response drills with local emergency responders; ammonia sensors located at critical locations in the process area and along the facility perimeter; continuous computer monitoring of ammonia sensor readings and weather conditions; and water spray systems for ammonia vapor suppression. 



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps:

The Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, 29 CFR 1910.119. As recognized by EPA, the PSM standard forms the basis for the agency's RMP prevention program component. The primary purpose of this facility's PSM program is to safeguard employees and nearby neighbors from exposure to ammonia by providing assistance in evaluating and updating the facility's process and mechanical safety procedures and programs. 



Key elements of the Port Sutton Ammonia Terminal prevention program are:

1) The facility has automated emergency shutdown systems with isolation valves to minimize a potential release; 

2) Contin

uous monitoring and surveillance are conducted by operating personnel via computer and remote cameras;

3) System design incorporates multiple layers of protection including: flare system, emergency power sources, pressure relied valves, and leak detectors

4) Plant personnel receive Process Safety Management training;

5) Traffic is strictly controlled throughout the facility; and 

6) Site access is controlled and monitored.



Five Year Accident History:

Details pertaining to the only accidental release from a covered process that has occurred at the Port Sutton Terminal within the past five (5) years have been included in Section 6 of this RMP Submittal document.  



Emergency Response Program:

HAZMAT training is performed in accordance with OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120(q) and pre-emergency planning and drills are conducted with local emergency responders. The emergency response program complies with the OSHA PSM Program as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Port Sutton personnel are committed to implementing, reviewing and updating the facility's Process Safety Management Program to ensure the highest standards are met for the continued safe operation of the Ammonia Terminal. In addition, Tampa Port Services, LLC will continue to provide support to and work with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and emergency responders to plan for the appropriate emergency response and to prepare for responding to an emergency through practice and drills.
